(Hint can be re-enabled from the menu button.)

The Rosie the Riveter Monument honors the contributions of women to the home front effort in World War 2. It is located on the site of Kaiser Shipyard #2 where many women worked alongside men to build Liberty and Victory Ships. The monument represents the bow, stern and steam stack of a Liberty ship. 

The walkway to the bay is the same length as the keel of a Liberty ship (441 feet). The walk is a timeline that tells the story of the national home front during World War 2. As you follow the timeline you can imagine the Liberty ships under construction, lined up side-by-side, roughly where the monument stands today. Be sure to view your position in the Kaiser shipyards on the "SHIPYARDS" tab of this app.

The monument was designed by Cheryl Barton and Susan Schwartzenberg and was dedicated on October 14, 2000.
Rosie the Riveter Monument, portion of the walkway in the foreground.

The SS Red Oak Victory is the only ship built in the Kaiser shipyards that is being restored. It is a Victory class cargo ship that was launched November 9, 1944. She was transferred from the Merchant Marines to the US Navy December 5, 1944 and converted at Port Chicago to carry munitions.

The Red Oak Victory operated in the Marshall and Caroline Islands and the Philippines, distributing munitions to ships in the Pacific Fleet. She was decommissioned in 1946 and subsequently served as a cargo ship until 1968. Mothballed in the National Defense Reserve Fleet in Suisun Bay, she was saved from the scrapyard by the Richmond Museum Association in 1993. Since then a dedicated group of volunteers has worked diligently to restore the ship.

As a munitions ship the Red Oak Victory was essentially a floating bomb, carrying up to 4,000 tons of munitions. This was extremely hazardous duty for the crewmen. An explosion due to accident or enemy action would instantly kill all on board. Nevertheless, the Red Oak Victory did not suffer a single casualty during her tour of duty.

Victory Ships were designed as an improvement over the Liberty Ship. At 455 feet long and 62 feet wide they were 14 foot longer and 5 foot wider. To escape enemy submarine action their top speed was 17 knots, 4 to 6 knots faster than a Liberty Ship. The first Victory Ship was launched in February 1944 and by the war's end 531 had been built - 142 of them here in Richmond.
SS Red Oak, a Victory class cargo ship built at Kaiser Shipyards
SS Red Oak Victory under construction in Kaiser Shipyard #1
Cross section of a Victory class ship
WW II hospital built for shipyard workers
Dangerous work - nationwide 700 shipyard workers were killed by accidents during the war. Shipbuilding had the highest rate of disabling injuries of all war production industries.

Opened August 10, 1942, the Kaiser Richmond Field Hospital was built to serve the employees of the Kaiser shipyards. It was financed by the U.S. Maritime Commission and sponsored by Henry Kaiser's Permanente Foundation. It was the second tier of a three tier medical care system. (First tier was on-site first aid stations; third tier the primary hospital in Oakland.) Initially built as a 10 bed facility, it was expanded to 160 beds by 1944.

Industrial accidents were a significant problem in World War 2, in fact up until D-Day more Americans were killed in home front industrial accidents than on the battlefield.

Henry Kaiser's solution to this problem was to offer a pre-paid health plan to his workers, one of the first voluntary pre-paid health plans in the country. By August 1944 92.2 percent of the shipyard workers had joined the plan. After the war the plan was expanded to cover employee families.

This innovative approach was a precursor to health maintanance organizations (HMOs) was the beginning of Kaiser Permanente, now the largest non-profit HMO in the country.

After the war, the hospital remained as part of Kaiser Permanente until replaced by a new Richmond facility in 1996.
Welcome to residents of the newly built project
Map outlining the boundaries of Atchison Village

Atchison Village was built in 1941 to house Kaiser Shipyard workers. It was funded by the Lanham Community Facilities Act. The Lanham Act provided $150 million to construct housing for defense workers. This funded construction of approximately 625,000 units throughout the country. Of the 20 World War 2 housing projects built in Richmond only Atchison Village, Nystrom Village and Triangle Court remain.

Atchison Village contains 97 one story buildings and 65 two story buildings, providing a total of 450 apartments.

 In 1956 the government sold Atchison Village to its inhabitants for $1.5 million. Today it remains a housing cooperative.

There was tremenous demand for new housing during the war. When World War 2 began the population of Richmond was 23,600. By 1943 it had increased to over 93,700. Housing was in such short supply that many Kaiser Shipyard employees "hot bunked" - at night the bed was used by a day shift worker, in the day by a night shift worker. In addition thousands commuted from elsewhere in the bay, so many that a railroad was built from Emeryville to Richmond to carry shipyard workers.
Completed Serman tank outside the Ford Plant

While the Kaiser Shipyards were the largest defense facilities in Richmond, there were others. The Ford Richmond Assembly Plant is an important example. Civilian automobile manufacturing was halted during World War 2 and the automobile plants were converted to support the war effort. Serving as the Richmond Tank Depot (one of three tank depots in the country) the Ford Plant supported the Pacific Theater. 49,225 jeeps were built here. In addition it performed final assembly on tanks, half-tracked armored personnel carriers and other military vehicles after their initial construction elsewhere. In this role it processed over 91,000 vehicles.

The plant has a history before and after the war in the construction of civilian automobiles. It was built in 1930 in the midst of the depression. The architect was Albert Kahn, noted for his industrial designs. His innovative use reinforced concrete enabled construction of factories with large open spaces lit by the significant use of windows. These stylistic hallmarks are visible in this building. Kahn designed the massive Ford Highland Park auto works built in 1917 to produce the Model T, the plant where Henry Ford perfected the assembly line. Kahn went on to design numerous auto plants as well as other important buildings.

Following the war, the Richmond plant returned to the construction of automobiles. The last car was constructed here in 1953.

The building was seriously damaged in the Loma Prieta earthquake in 1989. The City of Richmond took on the repair of the building, a project that was completed in 2008. It now houses light industry and a restaurant. The large Craneway Pavilion, with its wall of windows facing the bay, is rented for special events.

 You can view the first car to roll off of the assembly line here at the Richmond Museum of History.
Day care center built for shipyard workers\' children
Interior access by appointment and on scheduled ranger-led tours. Contact NPS for details.
Rear of the center - note porthole-style windows
A Rosie and her child at the center
A game of Chinese checkers. The center was furnished with child-size furniture.

The Maritime Child Center was built in 1943 to provide child care for the employees of the Kaiser Shipyards. It was funded by the U.S. Maritime Commission at the request of Henry Kaiser. While commonplace today, the working mother was uncommon prior to World War 2. Day care was an innovative concept. Under Kaiser\'s direction about 35 day care centers were constructed in Richmond for the children of the shipyard workers. Kaiser hired child development experts from UC Berkeley and elsewhere to assist in the creation of education and child care programs. Catherine Landreth from UC Berkeley oversaw the enterprise. The day care centers had outdoor space for fresh air and exercise and art and music were included as part of their curriculum. The children received warm meals, medical attention and had beds available. Warm meals could be purchased and taken home for the children and their families. The centers were open 24 hours and the employees could drop the children off when they worked night shifts.\n\nThis center and the Ruth Powers Child Development Center on Cutting Boulevard are the only World War 2 facilities remaining. After recent rehabilitation, they continue to serve the purpose for which they were built.
The General Warehouse, used to store ship fittings (furniture, blankets, mops, etc.)
Whirley Cranes were key to Henry Kaiser\'s methods, manipulating pre-fabricated parts into place for welding.
Riggers Loft included a sheet metal shop and a paint shop

Kaiser Shipyard #3 is the best preserved of the four Richmond shipyards. It is also the only one of the four intended to be a permanent shipyard. Today you can still view five World War 2 era buildings: the massive concrete General Warehouse, Riggers Loft, the machine shop, the first aid station and the cafeteria. The General Warehouse was used to store the many items - from furniture to blankets and brooms - required to fit out a ship. Riggers Loft, completed in 1942 was used to assemble prefabricated ship parts. Its 25000 square foot open space interior has 25 foot ceilings. There is a World War 2 Whirley Crane, so-called for their ability to turn 360 degrees. Behind the General Warehouse there are five graving/dry docks used for the construction of the ships. These are not currently viewable. Shipyard #3 is also home to the SS Red Oak Victory.

Cargo ships were crucial for winning the war, providing a lifeline to the United Kingdom as well as supplying United States military operations. During World War 2 the four Richmond shipyards produced 747 ships, primarily Liberty and Victory class cargo ships. Henry Kaiser developed mass production techniques that enabled his shipyards to produce ships at two-thirds the time and a quarter the cost of other shipyards. To accomplish this he introduced innovations drawn from automobile assembly lines and his own experience on dam building projects. He used modular, pre-fabricated construction. Large pre-made parts were moved into place by the Whirley Cranes and then welded together by "Wendy the Welder" and her male counterparts. Welding - as opposed to riveting - simplified the operation and reduced training time. As on assembly lines, workers were typically trained in a single skill. Unskilled workers could be assigned to perform simple repetative tasks. By 1944 the shipyards routinely built ships in two week's time and on one occasion built the Liberty ship SS Robert E. Peary in 5 days in a shipyard competition.

The Richmond shipyards workforce reached 30,000 within one month of the Pearl Harbor attack. At their peak they employed about 90,000, 27% of whom were women.

Rosie the Riveter/World War 2 Home Front National Historic Park consists of a number of sites scattered throughout Richmond. Together they tell the story of the World War 2 home front effort, in particular the contributions of women.

This app serves a guide to the park and an introduction to the shipbuilding effort centered in Richmond.

The Shipyards tab maps World War 2 arial photographs of the Kaiser shipyards over a satellite map of modern Richmond. Use Show my location to see where you are in the 1942 shipyards as you walk the site.

The Sites tab shows sites that relate to the park; the More tab shows other Bay Area sites related to World War 2. Each site entry provides visiting information, historic background, modern and historic photos and turn-by-turn directions.

Every site has an Add to tour button. Tap this to select this site for your visit. The site then appears on the My Tour tab. Use the up/down arrows to change the site position on your tour. Swipe across to remove it. You can see the distance and average driving times between the sites and have access to all site information including turn-by-turn directions.

The Album tab is a scrapbook of sounds and images from the home front.

One note about the High res photos menu option. When enabled, higher resolution photos will be used on the Shipyards tab. This can cause problems on some devices. If after enabling the app stops working, disable the option.

Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial
Memorial to those killed in the WWII munitions explosion.
Site of the worst home front disaster of WWII.
Access by prior apointment only. Contact NPS at the above address.
Shuttle bus from John Muir National Historic Site

Port Chicago was a supply depot used to load munitions on ships to supply the Pacific Theater. The first ship was loaded December 8, 1942. The enlisted men unloaded munitions brought in by train and loaded the ships by hand, winch and crane. Munitions processed here included high explosive bombs, shells and torpedoes.

 The enlisted men loading the ships were entirely African American. The officers were entirely white. The loaders were poorly trained and the officers inexperienced in managing munitions handling. There was significant tension as the loaders felt they were pressed into unsafe procedures to improve the speed of the operation.

On December 17, 1944 disaster struck. The Liberty ship SS E.A. Bryan was being loaded with high explosives at Pier 1. Alongside the Victory ship SS Quinault Victory was being prepared for loading. The munitions loaded on the ship and that on the pier totaled the equivalent of about 2,000 tons of TNT. There was an explosion and fire on the pier followed by a huge explosion as the munitions on the ship and pier detonated.

 The 320 military personnel on the pier died instantly. An additional 390 civilians and military personnel were injured. The E.A. Bryan was immediately destroyed and the Quinault was torn into pieces. Pilots flying overhead reported debris tossed 12,000 feet in the air. The explosion was heard throughout the East Bay and rattled windows as far south as Fremont, 45 miles away. Seismographs at UC Berkeley measured the shock waves as the equivalent of a 3.4 earthquake.

This was by far the worst disaster of the World War 2 home front. The exact cause of the explosion was never determined.

Following the Port Chicago disaster, surviving personnel were assigned to Mare Island Navel Base, reinforced with new recruits, and again assigned to load munitions. 258 refused citing continued dangerous practices. 208 were court-martialed for disobeying orders and given bad conduct discharges. 50 were court-martialed for mutiny and sentenced to 8 to 15 years hard labor. They are known today as the Port Chicago 50. They were granted clemency in 1946 but legal and political struggles that surrounded them continue to this day.

In many minds the story of the Port Chicago disaster and the Port Chicago 50 came to represent the unfairness of a segregated military. In 1945, partially in response to these events, the Navy began moving toward full desegregation, which became manditory by presidential decree in 1948. The disaster and its aftermath was a pivotal point in the African American struggle for equal rights.
Active military base. Entry by reservation only. Contact NPS for details.

Firehouse 67a was built in 1943. It was designed to house three trucks with men sleeping upstairs. 1943 also saw the completion of a new 8 man fire house at 41st and Clinton and the expansion of the fire house at 31st and Cutting.

 Enhancing community fire protection was of critical importance. The new shipyards needed protection from fire due to accident, sabotage and, potentially, enemy attack. Thousands of new housing units were being built in Richmond - these needed protection as well.

 The explosive growth of the Kaiser shipyards and Richmond itself placed great demands on the supporting infrastructure. Roads, public transit, schools, police and fire protection struggled to meet the expanded demands. The effort was made more challanging by the wartime restrictions on materials and workforce. Even shops and movie houses were overwhelmed by the new demand, often staying open 24 hours a day.
We do not collect or store any of your private information.

We do not transmit any information about you from your mobile device with one exception: when you request directions we transmit your current location to Google to generate a route to your desired location. We make no additional use of this information.
